hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the binary tree. Each node has a left and right child, and you will need to traverse the tree to find the target node.
Consider how you will represent the binary tree in your code. You might use a class for the nodes with properties for the value, left child, and right child.
When you find the target node, you need to look for its nearest right node. Think about what 'nearest' means in the context of a binary tree.
If the target node is the rightmost node at its level, there won't be a nearest right node. Make sure to handle this case appropriately.
You can use a breadth-first search (BFS) approach to traverse the tree level by level, which helps in finding nodes at the same level easily.
As you perform the BFS, keep track of the nodes at the current level. You can use a queue to facilitate this traversal.
While processing each level, note the position of the target node. If you find it, check the next node in the queue for the nearest right node.
Make sure to account for edge cases, such as when the tree is empty or when the target node is not present in the tree.
Remember that the input is given as an array representation of the binary tree. You will need to convert this array into an actual tree structure before processing.
When you find the nearest right node, ensure you return it in the correct format, which is typically the node itself or null if no such node exists.

questionNotes: The input is a binary tree represented as an array, where null indicates the absence of a node.
The target node's value is guaranteed to be present in the tree.
If the target node is the rightmost node at its level, return null.
